title: Ambiguous type casting behaviour when an overflow occurs in a range; to avoid this warn(overflowing_literals) should actually be an error

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

body:
### I tried this code:

[[play]](https://play.rust-lang.org/?gist=ab1580be944e9d95ec7a0f203250f73d&version=stable)
```rust
fn main() {
    let mut n: u8;
    
    for i in 0..256 {
        n = i;
        
        println!("{}:{}", n, i);
    }
}
```

### I expected to see this happen:
Output:

    0:0
    1:1
    ...
    254:254
    255:255

### Instead, this happened:
Output:

    Nothing

-------

Additionally, using `as u8` when performing the assignment makes it work correctly:
[[play]](https://play.rust-lang.org/?gist=4505842eb9b2104900f1abd1ae279374&version=stable)

```rust
fn main() {
    let mut n: u8;
    
    for i in 0..256 {
        n = i as u8;
        
        println!("{}:{}", n, i);
    }
}
```

Output:

    0:0
    1:1
    ...
    254:254
    255:255

-------

This doesn't make sense to me because the range is exclusive for the end parameter, so `for i in 0..256` would never overflow a `u8`.

-------

## Meta

`rustc --version --verbose`:  

    rustc 1.18.0 (03fc9d622 2017-06-06)
    binary: rustc
    commit-hash: 03fc9d622e0ea26a3d37f5ab030737fcca6928b9

    release: 1.18.0
    LLVM version: 3.9
